title: Section 3.16: Rules on Attendance
content: Attendance Requirements: - Minimum 80% attendance in all subjects required - 3 tardiness equals 1 absence - Absences exceeding 20% result in automatic failure - Medical absences require doctor's certificate - Excused absences: family emergency, medical reasons

title: Section 3.17: Dean's Honors List
content: Requirements for Dean's List: - Minimum GPA of 1.75 with no grade below 2.0 - Enrolled in at least 15 units - No disciplinary record during the semester - No incomplete grades

title: Section 3.18: Graduation, Academic Honors and Awards
content: ### Graduation Requirements: - Complete all required courses in curriculum - Minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0 - Complete 120 hours of community service - Pass comprehensive examination (if required) - Settle all financial and property obligations ### Academic Honors: - Summa Cum Laude: GPA 1.20-1.00 - Magna Cum Laude: GPA 1.45-1.21 - Cum Laude: GPA 1.75-1.46

title: Section 3.19: Institute of General Education
content: Provides foundational courses: - English Communication - Mathematics and Natural Sciences - Social Sciences and Philosophy - Physical Education and Health - All students must complete GE requirements School Logo, Colors and Motto Vision, Mission and Dynamic Filipinism NU Core Values NU Graduate Attributes Intended for Nationalians (NU GAINs) Quality Policy Data Privacy Policy

title: Section 1.1: General Norms
content: Students must maintain the highest standards of academic integrity and conduct themselves according to university policies and procedures.

title: Section 1.2: Rules of Conduct
content: All students are expected to: - Respect faculty, staff, and fellow students - Follow university policies and procedures - Maintain academic honesty - Participate actively in learning activities - Take responsibility for their academic progress

title: Section 1.3: Academic Integrity
content: Academic dishonesty includes: - Cheating during examinations - Plagiarism in written assignments - Falsification of documents - Unauthorized collaboration Violations result in failing grades, suspension, or dismissal.

title: Section 1.4: Student ID
content: All students must carry their official student identification card at all times on campus. Lost IDs must be replaced immediately through the registrar's office for a fee of ₱500.

title: Section 1.5: Uniform Policy
content: Students must wear prescribed uniforms: - Collared shirts or blouses (white or navy blue) - Appropriate pants or skirts (knee-length minimum) - Closed shoes (no slippers or sandals) - Laboratory classes require closed shoes and long pants

title: Section 1.6: Suspension of Classes
content: Classes are suspended during: - Typhoons and severe weather conditions - National holidays - Emergency situations Official announcements are made through NUIS and university website.

title: Section 2.1: Required Documents for Admission
content: ### For Freshman Students: - High School Report Card (Form 138) - original copy - Certificate of Good Moral Character - Birth Certificate (NSO/PSA issued) - Medical Certificate from licensed physician - Two (2) recent 2x2 ID pictures - Entrance examination results (if applicable) ### For Transfer Students: - Certificate of Transfer Credential/Honorable Dismissal - Official Transcript of Records - Certificate of Good Moral Character - Birth Certificate (NSO/PSA issued) - Medical Certificate

title: Section 2.2: General Admission Guidelines
content: ### Academic Requirements: - Minimum GPA of 2.5 for regular admission - Minimum GPA of 2.0 for conditional admission - GPA of 1.75 or higher for scholarship consideration - Passing score on entrance examination (if required) ### Application Process: 1. Submit complete admission requirements 2. Take entrance examination (if applicable) 3. Attend admission interview 4. Await admission decision 5. Confirm enrollment and pay required fees

title: Section 3.1: Student Classification
content: - Regular Student: Enrolled in minimum 15 units per semester - Irregular Student: Enrolled in less than 15 units - Special Student: Non-degree seeking - Graduate Student: Enrolled in master's or doctoral program

title: Section 3.2: Submission of Academic Credentials
content: All academic records must be submitted within 30 days of enrollment. Failure to comply results in non-issuance of grades and certificates.

title: Section 3.3: Registration and Enrollment
content: Registration periods: - Advance registration: May for 1st semester, November for 2nd semester - Regular registration: June for 1st semester, January for 2nd semester - Late registration: Additional fees apply after regular period

title: Section 3.4: Cross Enrollment
content: Students may enroll in other institutions with: - Prior approval from Academic Dean - Signed cross-enrollment agreement - Courses must be equivalent to NU curriculum

title: Section 3.5: Grading System
content: NU uses a grade point system with the following marks: - 4.0: Excellent (96–100%) - 3.5: Very Good (90–95%) - 3.0: Good (84–89%) - 2.5: Above Satisfactory (78–83%) - 2.0: Satisfactory (72–77%) - 1.5: Fair (66–71%) - 1.0: Pass (60–65%) - R: <60 (Repeat; not included in GWA) - 0.0: Failed - Dr: Officially Dropped - Inc: Incomplete - P/F: Pass/Fail used only for bridging and intervention courses (P ≥ 60; F < 60). Note: A 0.0 due to absences or academic dishonesty is carried over from midterm to final and cannot be changed to Dr after the midterm deadline.

title: Section 3.6: Crediting and Evaluation
content: Transfer credits are evaluated by the Office of the Registrar based on: - Course content equivalency - Number of units - Grade received (minimum 2.0) - Accreditation status of previous institution

title: Section 3.7: Academic Load
content: ### Regular Semester: - Minimum: 15 units - Normal: 18-21 units - Maximum: 24 units (with Dean's approval) ### Summer Term: - Maximum: 12 units - Remedial courses only - No overload permitted

title: Section 3.8: Shifting to Another Program
content: Requirements for program change: - Minimum GPA of 2.0 in current program - Letter of intent addressed to Dean - Approval from both current and receiving departments - May be required to take additional entrance examinations

title: Section 3.9: Load Revision
content: Students may add or drop subjects during: - First week of classes (100% refund for dropped subjects) - Second week of classes (75% refund) - No changes allowed after second week

title: Section 3.10: Enrollment Withdrawal
content: Complete withdrawal requires: - Clearance from all departments - Settlement of all financial obligations - Return of university property - Exit interview with guidance counselor

title: Section 3.11: Official Dropping
content: Official dropping procedures: - Submit dropping form to registrar - Obtain signatures from subject teacher and dean - Settle financial obligations - Deadline: Before midterm examinations

title: Section 3.12: Petition of Course(s)
content: Students may petition to take courses through: - Letter to Academic Dean - Valid academic reasons - Approval from department head - Payment of petition fees

title: Section 3.13: Substitution of Course(s)
content: Course substitution allowed for: - Discontinued subjects - Equivalent courses from other institutions - Program curriculum changes - Must be approved by Academic Dean

title: Section 3.14: Discontinuance of Studies / Transfer Credentials
content: Transfer credentials include: - Official Transcript of Records - Certificate of Transfer Credential - Certificate of Good Moral Character - Fees: ₱500 for transcript, ₱200 for certificates

title: Section 4.1: Schedule of Fees and Other Charges
content: ### Undergraduate Programs (per semester): - Tuition per unit: ₱2,800 - Miscellaneous fees: ₱18,500 - Laboratory fee: ₱3,500 (if applicable) - Internet fee: ₱1,000 - Student activity fee: ₱500 - ID replacement: ₱500 ### Graduate Programs (per semester): - Master's programs: ₱3,200 per unit - Doctoral programs: ₱3,500 per unit - Thesis fee: ₱25,000 - Comprehensive exam fee: ₱5,000

title: Section 4.2: Payment of Fees and Other Charges
content: ### Payment Options: 1. Full payment upon enrollment (5% discount) 2. Two installments: 60% upon enrollment, 40% before midterm 3. Three installments: 40% enrollment, 30% midterm, 30% finals 4. Promissory note (with requirements)

title: Section 4.3: Available Payment Channels
content: - University cashier (cash, check, credit card) - Online banking (BPI, BDO, Metrobank) - Over-the-counter bank payments - GCash and PayMaya - Installment through credit card

title: Section 4.4: Refund
content: Refund Schedule: - 100% refund: withdrawal within 1 week of enrollment - 80% refund: withdrawal within 2 weeks - 60% refund: withdrawal within 3 weeks - 40% refund: withdrawal within 4 weeks - No refund after 4 weeks of classes

title: Section 4.5: Non-settlement of Financial or Property Accounts
content: Consequences of unpaid accounts: - Non-issuance of grades and certificates - Non-enrollment for succeeding semester - Withholding of transcript and diploma - Referral to collection agency for overdue accounts

title: Section 4.6: NUIS Student Ledger
content: Students can access financial records through: - NUIS (NU Information System) - Real-time balance updates - Payment history - Outstanding obligations - Statement of account generation

title: Section 4.7: Application for Promissory
content: Promissory Note Requirements: - Letter of request to Finance Office - Financial hardship documentation - Guarantor with stable income - Collateral or security deposit - Approval from Finance Director

title: Section 15.5: What does AIPO do?
content: # Appendices ## A. Student Etiquette ## B. Primer of RA 10627: The Anti-Bullying Act ## C. Academic Programs of National University Main ## D. National University Main Office Directory
